ACT230H1-F-20219.courseDescription: Introduction to financial mathematics, interest measurement, present value calculation, annuity valuation, loan amortization, consumer financing arrangements, bond valuation. The course is aimed at a general audience who will not be continuing in the actuarial science program. Course manuals fee: $30.
ACT230H1-F-20219.deliveryInstructions:
Lectures will be delivered online and tests,  tutorials and office hours will be offered in-person.  Details about the course meeting schedule, as well as other course activities and assessments, will be communicated in the course syllabus and/or on Quercus.  

It is strongly recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in any online components of this course.

ACT240H1-F-20219.courseDescription: Interest, discount and present values, as applied to determine prices and values of annuities, mortgages, bonds, equities; loan repayment schedules and consumer finance payments in general; yield rates on investments given the costs on investments. Course manuals fee: $45.
ACT240H1-F-20219.deliveryInstructions:
Lectures will be delivered online and tests,  tutorials and office hours will be offered in-person.  Details about the course meeting schedule, as well as other course activities and assessments, will be communicated in the course syllabus and/or on Quercus.  

It is strongly recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in any online components of this course.

ACT245H1-S-20219.courseTitle: Financial Principles for Actuarial Science I
ACT245H1-S-20219.courseDescription: Term structure of interest rates, cashflow duration, convexity and immunization, forward and futures contracts, interest rate swaps, introduction to investment derivatives and hedging strategies.
ACT245H1-S-20219.deliveryInstructions:
Lectures and office hours will be delivered online and tests and  tutorials will be offered in-person.  Details about the course meeting schedule, as well as other course activities and assessments, will be communicated in the course syllabus and/or on Quercus. 

It is strongly recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in any online components of this course.

ACT247H1-S-20219.courseDescription: Probability theory applied to survival and to costs and risks of life assurances, life annuities, and pensions; analysis of survival distributions; international actuarial notation. Course manuals fee: $35.
ACT247H1-S-20219.deliveryInstructions:
Lectures, tutorials and tests will be in-person, office hours will be online. Details about the course meeting schedule, as well as other course activities and assessments, will be communicated in the course syllabus and/or on Quercus. 

It is strongly recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in any online components of this course.

ACT348H1-F-20219.courseDescription: Determination of benefit premium and benefit reserves for life insurance and annuities; analysis of insurance loss random variables; theory of life contingencies for multiple lives. Course manuals fee: $40.
ACT348H1-F-20219.deliveryInstructions:
Some of the scheduled in-person lectures may be offered online depending on current public health and institutional guidelines. Details about the course meeting schedule, as well as other course activities and assessments, will be communicated in the course syllabus and/or on Quercus.  

It is strongly recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in any online components of this course.

ACT349H1-F-20219.courseDescription: Actuarial applications of financial mathematics and economics.
ACT349H1-F-20219.deliveryInstructions:
Some of the scheduled in-person lectures may be offered online depending on current public health and institutional guidelines. Details about the course meeting schedule, as well as other course activities and assessments, will be communicated in the course syllabus and/or on Quercus.  

It is strongly recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in any online components of this course.

ACT350H1-F-20219.courseDescription:
The course offers an introduction to elementary probability theory and stochastic processes. The main goal of the course is to help actuarial students understand the concept of stochastic processes with particular emphasis on Markov chains that are of great importance in Life Contingencies and Property and Casualty insurance.


The course will cover the following topics: a basic review of probabilities with emphasis on conditional probabilities and expectations, discrete time Markov chains, Poisson processes, continuous time Markov chains, renewal theory and some applications, queueing theory.
ACT350H1-F-20219.prerequisite: ACT240H1 (minimum 63%); ACT245H1 (minimum 63%); ACT247H1 (minimum 63%); STA257H1, MAT223H1/MAT240H1, MAT237Y1/MAT257Y1
ACT350H1-F-20219.deliveryInstructions:
Pre-recorded lectures will be offered online and tutorials and computer labs will be in-person depending on current public health and institutional guidelines. Details about the course meeting schedule, as well as other course activities and assessments, will be communicated in the course syllabus and/or on Quercus. 

It is strongly recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in any online components of this course.

ACT370H1-S-20219.courseTitle: Financial Principles for Actuarial Science II
ACT370H1-S-20219.courseDescription: Mathematical theory of financial derivatives, discrete and continuous option pricing models, hedging strategies and exotic option valuation.
ACT370H1-S-20219.deliveryInstructions:
Lectures and tutorials and tests will be in-person, office hours will be online. Details about the course meeting schedule, as well as other course activities and assessments, will be communicated in the course syllabus and/or on Quercus. 

It is strongly recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in any online components of this course.

ACT371H1-F-20219.courseTitle: Basic Reserving Methods For P&C Insurance
ACT371H1-F-20219.courseDescription: Topics covered include reserving data and triangles, diagnoses methods that range from triangle of ratios of paid claims to reported claims to triangle of reported claim ratios. The syllabus also includes projection techniques. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
ACT371H1-F-20219.deliveryInstructions:
Lectures will be in-person lectures weeks and online in others, or other ways of hybrid models including in person office hours.

Some of the scheduled in-person lectures may be offered online depending on current public health and institutional guidelines. Details about the course meeting schedule, as well as other course activities and assessments, will be communicated in the course syllabus and/or on Quercus.  

It is strongly recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in any online components of this course.

ACT372H1-S-20219.courseTitle: Basic Ratemaking Methods For P&C Insurance
ACT372H1-S-20219.courseDescription: This course covers the basic ratemaking methods for P&C insurance. It assumes that students are familiar with traditional reserving diagnoses and projection methods. The syllabus would introduce concepts related to earning of exposures, on-level factors, catastrophe loading, large loss loading and credibility. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
ACT372H1-S-20219.deliveryInstructions:
Lectures and tutorials and tests will be in-person, office hours will be online. Details about the course meeting schedule, as well as other course activities and assessments, will be communicated in the course syllabus and/or on Quercus. 

It is strongly recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in any online components of this course.

ACT390H1-F-20219.courseDescription: The professional experience is a mandatory course in the actuarial science Specialist program, in preparation for an internship work term after the PE course is completed. It includes various professional skill workshops, networking activities and an invited industry speaker series. (No tuition fee associated, however an ancillary fee of $550 will be assessed towards Professional Experience preparatory program costs.)
ACT390H1-F-20219.prerequisite: Enrolment in the Actuarial Science Specialist.
ACT390H1-F-20219.deliveryInstructions:
Lectures will be delivered online and tests tutorials and office hours will be offered in-person.  Details about the course meeting schedule, as well as other course activities and assessments, will be communicated in the course syllabus and/or on Quercus.  

It is strongly recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in any online components of this course.

ACT391H1-F-20219.courseDescription: Internship course for students enrolled in the Actuarial Science Specialist, fulfilled as a 12-week work term in a workplace related to actuarial science in third or fourth year. ACT390H1 must be completed first in preparation. Contact Department for more information. (No tuition fee associated, however an ancillary fee of $720 will be assessed towards Professional Experience placement.)
ACT391H1-F-20219.webTimetableInstructions: For “E” indicator courses: students should obtain an application form from Priya Sivathason, ug.actsci@utoronto.ca at the Department of Statistical Sciences, 700 University Avenue, Room 9160-6, Toronto, Ontario, M5G 1Z5.

ACT391H1-S-20219.courseDescription: Internship course for students enrolled in the Actuarial Science Specialist, fulfilled as a 12-week work term in a workplace related to actuarial science in third or fourth year. ACT390H1 must be completed first in preparation. Contact Department for more information. (No tuition fee associated, however an ancillary fee of $720 will be assessed towards Professional Experience placement.)
ACT391H1-S-20219.webTimetableInstructions: For “E” indicator courses: students should obtain an application form from Priya Sivathason, ug.actsci@utstat.utoronto.ca at the Department of Statistical Sciences, 700 University Avenue, Room 9160-6, Toronto, Ontario, M5G 1Z5.
ACT391H1-S-20219.deliveryInstructions: There will be no student contact as this an internship term.

ACT451H1-F-20219.courseDescription: Loss models policy adjustments, frequency and severity models, compound distributions.
ACT451H1-F-20219.deliveryInstructions:
Lectures will be delivered online and tests tutorials and office hours will be offered in-person.  Details about the course meeting schedule, as well as other course activities and assessments, will be communicated in the course syllabus and/or on Quercus.  

It is strongly recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in any online components of this course.

ACT452H1-S-20219.courseDescription: Estimation of Loss and Survival Models using complete, censored and truncated data. Product-Limit estimation, empirical estimation, moment and percentile estimation, maximum likelihood estimation and simulation models.
ACT452H1-S-20219.deliveryInstructions:
Lectures will be delivered online and office hours and tests will be given in-person. Details about the course meeting schedule, as well as other course activities and assessments, will be communicated in the course syllabus and/or on Quercus. 

It is strongly recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in any online components of this course.

ACT455H1-S-20219.courseDescription: Advanced life contingencies, multiple decrement theory, insurance policy expenses, multi-state transition models, Poisson processes.
ACT455H1-S-20219.deliveryInstructions:
In-person lectures and tests and online office hours/ Details about the course meeting schedule, as well as other course activities and assessments, will be communicated in the course syllabus and/or on Quercus. 

It is strongly recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in any online components of this course.

ACT460H1-F-20219.courseDescription: Applications of the lognormal distribution, Brownian motion, geometric Brownian motion, martingales, Ito's lemma, stochastic differential equations, interest rate models, the Black-Scholes model, volatility, value at risk, conditional tail expectation.
ACT460H1-F-20219.deliveryInstructions:
Lectures will be delivered online and tests tutorials and office hours will be offered in-person.  Details about the course meeting schedule, as well as other course activities and assessments, will be communicated in the course syllabus and/or on Quercus.  

It is strongly recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in any online components of this course.

ACT466H1-S-20219.courseDescription: Limited fluctuation credibility, Bayesian estimation, Buhlmann credibility, non-parametric credibility methods, inverse transformation simulation method, specialized simulation methods for the normal and lognormal distributions, Monte Carlo methods, the bootstrap method.
ACT466H1-S-20219.prerequisite: ACT240H1 (minimum 63%); ACT245H1 (minimum 63%); ACT247H1 (minimum 63%); STA261H1, ACT350H1/STA347H1, ACT451H1
ACT466H1-S-20219.deliveryInstructions:
In-person lectures and tests and online office hours/ Details about the course meeting schedule, as well as other course activities and assessments, will be communicated in the course syllabus and/or on Quercus. 

It is strongly recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in any online components of this course.

ACT470H1-S-20219.courseDescription: Topics in pension mathematics; funding methods for pension plans. (Offered in alternate years)
ACT470H1-S-20219.deliveryInstructions:
In-person lectures and tests and online office hours. Details about the course meeting schedule, as well as other course activities and assessments, will be communicated in the course syllabus and/or on Quercus. 

It is strongly recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in any online components of this course.

ACT473H1-S-20219.courseDescription: Case study approach to current issues in life insurance, pension consulting and casualty actuarial practice. The focus of the course will be on communication and presentation. This course is Pass/Fail. Not eligible for Credit/No Credit. The course is open to students in the specialist program in actuarial science. Students in the major program in actuarial science can enrol into the course with permission of the department.
ACT473H1-S-20219.deliveryInstructions:
In-person lectures and tutorials and online office hours. Details about the course meeting schedule, as well as other course activities and assessments, will be communicated in the course syllabus and/or on Quercus. 

It is strongly recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in any online components of this course.

ACT497H1-S-20219.courseDescription: Independent study under the direction of a faculty member. Persons wishing to take this course must have the permission of the Undergraduate Secretary and of the prospective supervisor. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
